Histamine UrineAlternative Names:Methyl-Histamine UrineLaboratory:Clinical BiochemistryTest Code:UMEHITSpecimen Types:Urine 24 hourContainer Types:Urine Bottle ACIDCollection & Request Instructions:Aids in diagnosis of mastocytosisTransport Instructions between Sites and/or Laboratories:Room TemperatureExternal Laboratory:The Children's Hospital at WestmeadAdditional Notes:SPECIAL DIET

Urinary Catecholamine, Histamine & 5-HIAA Estimation 

This special diet was designed by the Departments of Clinical Biochemistry and Nutrition and Dietetics and is suitable for both adults and children having urine collected for catecholamines, histamine or serotonin studies.

The diet must be followed for 24 hours prior to and also during the course of urine collection. 

Avoid the following: 

Fruit: Bananas, canned and fresh pineapple, plum, grapes, kiwifruit, avocado, cherries, blueberries, raspberries, strawberries, blackcurrants, oranges, guava, mango, passionfruit, dried fruit.

Jams:All except apricot.

Vegetables:Tomatoes, mushrooms, spinach, broccoli, brussel sprouts, cauliflower, eggplant, broadbeans, pickled vegetables eg sauerkraut.

Nuts & Seeds: All including peanut butter and tahini

Dairy: All cheeses and cheese spreads, yoghurt flavoured with nuts, muesli containing nuts or above fruits, chocolate yogo, banana strawberry and chocolate flavoured milk, fruit smoothies.

Fish & Seafood: All including canned, fried and salted fish and seafood.

Chocolate:All forms including Cocoa and Milo.

Processed Meats: All including devon, salami, sausages, ham, chicken loaf, turkey loaf.

Condiments: All chutneys and also malted or coloured vinegar, mayonnaise & tartare sauce.

Fermented Foods: Yeast extracts eg Marmite, Vegemite, fish paste, fish sauce, soy sauce, meat gravy.

Drinks: All wine and beer (all fermented beverages). Juices of all fruit listed above.

 

The following foods are allowed: 

Rice: Brown or white, rice cakes – avoid any rice product containing nuts, seeds, fruit or flavouring as listed above.

Bread & Cereals: All plain bread and breakfast cereals, whole meal and white flour products except those containing nuts, seeds, fruit, flavourings or fillings as listed above.

Pasta: Including spaghetti or noodles. Avoid those containing nuts, seeds, fruit, flavouring or fillings as listed above eg. Avoid ravioli and coloured pastas.

Confectionery :Brown or white sugar. Boiled and jelly sweets.

Fresh fruit: Apples, pears, apricots, peaches, rockmelon, watermelon.

Vegetables: All fresh vegetables not listed above.

Coconut: Including coconut milk.

Dairy: Fresh milk, fresh cream, vanilla yoghurt, plain ice cream and custard, (artificial) strawberry yogo.

Meats: All freshly prepared meats, including chicken.

Eggs: Whole eggs, egg white and yolk are allowed.

Spreads: Apricot jam and honey.

Condiments: Clear vinegar, vanilla, nutmeg, powdered stock (eg for gravy) may be used only if freshly prepared.

Drinks: Milk, milkshakes (vanilla, coffee, plain or caramel flavoured), lemonade, tea, coffee, apple juice.

 

Information sheet from The Children's Hospital at Westmead

https://www.slhd.nsw.gov.au/sswps/fact%20sheets/Sheet%2044.pdf

OsteocalcinLaboratory:Clinical BiochemistryTest Code:OSTEOCALCSpecimen Types:PlasmaContainer Types:EDTA 3 mLCollection & Request Instructions:Avoid hemolysis. Erythrocytes contain proteases which degrade Osteocalcin.  Centrifuge specimens immediately.

EDTA plasma preferred specimen for analysis.

EDTA plasma samples stable 2 days at 15-25C, 3 days at 2-8C, 3 mths at -20C. Feeze only once.

 

Serum levels reflect the extent of laying down of bone matrix. Useful in monitoring when this is affected by disease or drug therapy.Transport Instructions between Sites and/or Laboratories:Room TemperatureAssay Frequency:WeeklyAdditional Notes:Melbourne Health Pathology ceased Osteocalcin testing from 1/3/2019.

Contact Chemical Pathologist for any queries.

CalciumLaboratory:Clinical BiochemistryTest Code:CASpecimen Types:SerumPlasmaContainer Types:SSTLithium Heparin (with Gel)Collection & Request Instructions:Stasis must be avoided when taking blood as prolonged use of a torniquet gives falsely high values, as does haemolysis.Transport Instructions between Sites and/or Laboratories:Room TemperatureAdditional Notes:Reference Interval (Adults 19 yrs +):   

2.10—2.60 mmol/L

Source:

RCPA/AACB Harmonised Reference Intervals from 13/7/2015.

Serum total calcium rises or falls approximately
0.018 mmol/L for each g/L change in serum albumin.

Corrected calcium (CCA) will be automatically calculated when serum albumin is also requested.

CCA = Calcium Lvl+(40-Albumin Lvl)*0.018

Age Related Reference Intervals:

< 1 yrs                     2.13- 2.75 mmol/L

1 yr - < 19 yrs      2.3-2.63 mmol/L

row:
Mycophenolic AcidLaboratory:Clinical BiochemistryTest Code:MYCOPSpecimen Types:PlasmaContainer Types:EDTA 10 mLAdults Volume or Mass:5 mLCollection & Request Instructions:Collect pre-doseTransport Instructions between Sites and/or Laboratories:On IceAssay Frequency:WeeklyExternal Laboratory:Austin PathologyAdditional Notes:Pre-Dose - Pre-Dose sampling is useful for checking patient compliance or suspected toxicity. A universal reference range is not applicable.  Correlation between Pre-dose plasma levels of total MPA and clinical outcome depend on the specific clinical setting/patient population and have not been firmly established in some settings.

 

Mycophenolic acid (MPA) total, estimation of AUC 0-12 hr - plasma.

Estimation of AUC 0-12 hr uses a limited sampling approach.  It requires 4 samples (Pre-dose, +1hr, +2 hr, +4hr post dose).

FORMS to be COMPLETED and sent to lab with the samples.

To ensure capture of all data a completed copy of the specific form -downloadable from www.austinpathology.org.au/test-directory      MUST be sent to the lab with the samples for the MPAAUC tests.

A reference range is currently being established. In renal and cardiac transplant recipients an AUC 0-12 hr of 30 to 60 mg.hr/L in the initial phase after transplantation has been shown to associate with less rejection (see Elbarbry FA and Shoker AS, 2007, Clin. Biochem 40:752 for review).

For further information please contact Andrew Ellis, Clinical    Pharmacology and Therapeutics Unit, Austin Pathology on 94963220.

Chemical Pathologist/Registrar approval required - to ensure all forms completed and samples (AUC) collated - prior to sending to Austin Pathology

transport: On Ice
external: Austin Pathology

row:
TPMT Phenotype+/- GenotypeAlternative Names:Thiopurine Methyl TransferaseLaboratory:Clinical BiochemistryTest Code:TPMTSpecimen Types:BloodContainer Types:EDTA 10 mLCollection & Request Instructions:Used for the identification of patients at risk of myelosuppression prior to initiation of thiopurine drug therapy (e.g. azothioprine, 6-mercaptopurine, thioguanine). We are now sending TPMT tests to PathWest (QEII Medical Centre, WA) who offer a comprehensive, sequential TPMT testing service. TPMT Phenotype, which measures thiopurine methyltransferase activity, is the first-line test and if it is normal no further testing is indicated. If TPMT Phenotype is abnormal, it is automatically followed by the TPMT Genotype test which screens for the common TPMT mutations. There are rare mutations not detected by this Genotype test. An abnormal Phenotype which is not associated with common mutations will prompt sequencing of the entire coding region of the TPMT gene to detect rare mutations. Transport Instructions between Sites and/or Laboratories:Room TemperatureAssay Frequency:WeeklyExternal Laboratory:PathWest QEII Medical CentreAdditional Notes:Path West TPMT Lab Contact

Phone No: (08) 6383 4114

Fax No: (08) 6457 1322

Hydroxyproline UrineLaboratory:Clinical BiochemistryTest Code:UHYDTSpecimen Types:Urine 24 hourContainer Types:Urine Bottle PLAINCollection & Request Instructions:Dietary restriction or special diet.Foods containing appreciable amounts of collagen should be avoided in the 24 hrs prior to specimen collection. These foods include meats an meat products, gravy and even confectionary and ice-cream containing gelatin.

The patient fasts from 8pm on the night before collection. On waking the bladdder is voided and urine discarded. The next urine is collected 1-2 hours later at which time breakfast may be eaten.Transport Instructions between Sites and/or Laboratories:Room TemperatureAssay Frequency:FortnightlyExternal Laboratory:NSW Health Pathology, (SSWPS) - RPA

5 FlucytosineAlternative Names:FlucytosineLaboratory:Clinical BiochemistryTest Code:5FCSpecimen Types:PlasmaSerumContainer Types:Lithium Heparin (with Gel)SSTAdults Volume or Mass:1 mLMinimum/Paediatric Volume or Mass:1 mLCollection & Request Instructions:Melbourne Health Pathology(RMH) perfoms 5FC testing on Tuesday and Thursdays.

Cut-off time for RMH to receive the 5FC samples for analysis is 1200 hrs.

 Transport Instructions between Sites and/or Laboratories:On IceExternal Laboratory:Melbourne Health Shared Pathology ServiceAdditional Notes:5 FC Therapeutic range:

Mean steady-state levels of 35-70 mg/L recommended for effective antifungal therapy.  Levels >100 mg/L may be associated with bone marrow toxicity.

If Trough and Peak levels are measured- aim for a trough level of 25-50 mg/L and peak 30-80 mg/L

row:
FluconazoleLaboratory:Clinical BiochemistryTest Code:FLUCOSpecimen Types:PlasmaContainer Types:EDTA 10 mLAdults Volume or Mass:3 mLMinimum/Paediatric Volume or Mass:3 mLCollection & Request Instructions:Collect at steady state:Trough sampleTransport Instructions between Sites and/or Laboratories:Room TemperatureAssay Frequency:WeeklyAdditional Notes:A clear-cut therapeutic range has not been described. British guidelines (1) suggest the use of area under the curve (AUC- estimated from measurements at 1, 4 and 24 hours) over the minimal inhibitory concentration (MIC) of the organism and that >100 using the EUCAST method is associated with higher treatment success. A Brazilian study published recently describes serum levels between 20 and 40 mg/L in patients with neurocryptococcosis and that CSF levels correlate with serum levels. (2) Others (European Conference on Infections in Leukemia) suggest trough levels of > 10-15 mg/L as an alternative (see http://www.ecil-leukaemia.com/telechargements2015/ECIL6-Triazole-TDM-07-12-2015-Lewis-R-et-al.pdf ).

 

1. Ashbee HR et al. Therapeutic Drug Monitoring (TDM) of Antifungal Agents: Guidelines From the British Society for Medical Mycology. J Antimicrob Chemother. 2014 May;69(5):1162-76.  doi: 10.1093/jac/dkt508.  Epub 2013 Dec 29. 

2.Schiave LA, et al. Fluconazole levels in serum and cerebrospinal fluid according to daily dosage in patients with cryptococcosis and other fungal infections.  Braz J Infect Dis. 2018 Jan-Feb;22(1):11-15. doi: 10.1016/j.bjid.2017.10.003. Epub 2017 Nov 13.

row:
PosaconazoleLaboratory:Clinical BiochemistryTest Code:POSASpecimen Types:PlasmaContainer Types:EDTA 10 mLAdults Volume or Mass:5 mLCollection & Request Instructions:Collect pre-doseCollect samples Pre Dose

Do not use tubes with gel separator.

Assay run 3 x weekly  (Monday, Tuesday & Thursday) - samples must be in lab by 11AM on each day.                               Results available at end of the day.Transport Instructions between Sites and/or Laboratories:Room TemperatureAssay Frequency:3 x weekly (thrice)Additional Notes:Therapeutic Ranges for Posaconazole

 We suggest to monitor Posaconazole trough concentration at steady state (7 days after starting therapy). Levels ≥ 0.7 mg/L are required for prophylaxis and ≥ 1mg/L for invasive fungal infection. 

Reference Interval Source:

Chau M, Kong D, van Hal J et al. Consensus guidelines for optimising antifungal drug delivery and monitoring to avoid toxicity and improve outcomes in patients with haematological malignancy, 2014. Internal Medicine Journal 2014; 1364-1388.

Refer to Alfred PROMPT Posaconazole guideline for further details

row:
VoriconazoleLaboratory:Clinical BiochemistryTest Code:VORISpecimen Types:PlasmaContainer Types:EDTA 10 mLAdults Volume or Mass:5 mLCollection & Request Instructions:Collect pre-doseAssay run 3 x weekly  (Monday, Tuesday & Thursday) - samples must be in lab by 11AM on each day.                               Results available at the end of the day.Transport Instructions between Sites and/or Laboratories:Room TemperatureAssay Frequency:3 x weekly (thrice)Additional Notes:Therapeutic Range for Voriconazole

Monitoring Voriconazole trough concentration at steady state (after one week of initiation or change of therapy) can be clinically helpful. 

Suggested therapeutic range is: 1 - 5.5 mg/L.  Trough concentrations < 1 mg/L suggest inappropriate absorption and concentrations > 5.5 mg/L have been associated with toxicity.

(Dodds Ashley E and Perfect JR. Pharmacology of Azoles. UpToDate (accessed online 12/7/10)

Refer to Alfred PROMPT Voriconazole guideline for further details

CA 19-9Laboratory:Clinical BiochemistryTest Code:CA19Specimen Types:SerumPlasmaContainer Types:SSTLithium Heparin (with Gel)Collection & Request Instructions:Ca 19-9 should only be used for follow up of patients with histologically proven tumour and not for screening for cancer. Ca 19-9 is elevated in most pancreatic adenocarcinomas, around 50% of gastric carcinomas and 30% of colorectal carcinomas. The main function of Ca 19-9 measurement is surveillance and monitoring of therapy in patients with known pancreatic adenocarcinoma. ASCO guidelines suggest that an elevation of Ca 19-9 levels alone is insufficient for diagnosis of recurrence, and confirmation with imaging studies +/- biopsy is required.It may also be elevated in a number of benign conditions including pancreatitis and cirrhosis.

 Transport Instructions between Sites and/or Laboratories:Room TemperatureAdditional Notes:Reference Interval:

  96% of healthy subjects have CA 19-9 levels  <37 kU/L

Method used is Abbott Alinity (CMIA).


Reformulation of Ca 19-9 assay as of 1st October 2014. No clinically significant change in result expected. Reference Interval unchanged, please contact lab if there are any concerns.

Vitamin B12Alternative Names:B12Laboratory:Clinical BiochemistryTest Code:B12Specimen Types:SerumContainer Types:SSTCollection & Request Instructions:B12 results should be interpreted in the clinical context and in the light of other results available; e.g. FBE and Blood Film.

Only a minority of patients with B12 levels between 130-250 pmol/L will exhibit true deficiency.

A normal value does not exclude deficiency if there is a high index of suspicion clinically.Transport Instructions between Sites and/or Laboratories:Room TemperatureAdditional Notes:Reference Range:  150—857 pmol/L

Method used is Abbott Architect(CMIA).

Anti-TPO AntibodyAlternative Names:Anti-Thyroid Peroxidase AntibodiesLaboratory:Clinical BiochemistryTest Code:ATASpecimen Types:SerumContainer Types:SSTCollection & Request Instructions:Thyroid autoimmune disease is the major factor underlying hypothyroidism and hyperthyroidism and tends to occur in a genetically-predisposed population. In virtually all cases of Hashimoto’s disease and in the majority of Grave’s disease cases, TPO auto antibodies are elevated. Thyrotropin Receptor Antibodies may also aid the diagnosis of Graves Disease.Transport Instructions between Sites and/or Laboratories:Room TemperatureAdditional Notes:Assay performed on Roche Elecsys (ECLIA)

Reference Range:  < 34 IU/mL

Note: Biotin supplementation may cause falsely high results due to interference with the anti TPO Ab assay. If this patient is known to be taking Biotin, interpret results with caution and contact the Chemical Pathologist (03) 90763118 if further discussion is required.

row:
Factor VIIILaboratory:HaematologyTest Code:F8LSpecimen Types:PlasmaContainer Types:Sodium CitrateAdults Volume or Mass:2.7 mLCollection & Request Instructions:By consultation with Haematologist.

Specimens cannot be analysed or re-analysed greater than 2 hours after collection.

When the collection is by vacuum tube,the coagulation tube should be collected second to avoid artefactual shortening of coagulation assays due to the trauma of venesection.  When syringes are used, have ready two plastic syringes. A butterfly needle may be used. Withdraw 5 mL blood into the first syringe and discard the syringe (or use it for other tests). With the second syringe, withdraw the required amount of blood for the coagulation tests. When blood is collected from an arterial line it is necessary to discard the first 20mL of blood to clear any heparin from the line before collecting the blood for coagulation tests.Transport Instructions between Sites and/or Laboratories:Room TemperatureAdditional Notes:Reference Range: 50-150 %

C-TelopeptideAlternative Names:CTXLaboratory:Clinical BiochemistryTest Code:CTXSpecimen Types:PlasmaContainer Types:EDTA 6 mLSSTCollection & Request Instructions:Collect in amFasting SampleMarker of bone resorption. Useful for monitoring the effect of anti-resorptive therapy and patient compliance.

Plasma EDTA is the preferred sample as it is stable longer than serum.

Stability of K2- and K3-EDTA plasma: 24 hrs at 20-25C, 8 days at 2-8C

3 months at -20C. For longer periods store at -70C. Freeze only ONCE.

Serum is only stable 6 hrs at 20-25 C, 8 hrs at 4 - 8C,         3 months at -20C. For longer periods store at -70C. Freeze only ONCE

Haemolyzed samples (Hb> 0.5 g/dL) elicit a decrease in the C-Telopeptide (Beta- crosslaps) concentration.

 Transport Instructions between Sites and/or Laboratories:Send to lab immediatelyUse Esky from SDMH or CGMC to AlfredFor external sites transport to Alfred Pathology  Frozen.Assay Frequency:WeekdaysAdditional Notes:Reference Intervals:

row:
CreatinineLaboratory:Clinical BiochemistryTest Code:CRSpecimen Types:SerumPlasmaContainer Types:SSTLithium Heparin (with Gel)Transport Instructions between Sites and/or Laboratories:Room TemperatureAdditional Notes:Reference Intervals (Adult 19yrs+):

Male:       60—110  umol/L
Female:   45—90   umol/L

Source:

RCPA/AACB Harmonised Reference Intervals from 13/7/2015.

Falsely high creatinine values may be obtained in therapy with ascorbic acid and in the presence of ketones, alpha–methyldopa, haemolysis or high glucose concentrations.

Cephalosporins in high concentration also give falsely high serum creatinine. Blood samples for creatinine should not be taken within one hour of i.v. Cephalosporin administration.

Assay methods are affected differently by interferences. Where necessary to resolve discrepancies, an enzymatic method is available after consultation.

row:
Creatine KinaseAlternative Names:CKLaboratory:Clinical BiochemistryTest Code:CKSpecimen Types:SerumPlasmaContainer Types:SSTLithium Heparin (with Gel)Collection & Request Instructions:CK should be used only in the early stages of myocardial infarction. If the CK is normal shortly after onset of chest pain thought to be of myocardial origin then a repeat estimation 3—4 hours later may be helpful.
CK is less sensitive and less specific for the diagnosis of myocardial injury than Troponin I. Skeletal muscle CK is elevated in several situations, e.g. post–operatively, after intramuscular injections, following trauma or vigorous exercise, and in some diseases of skeletal muscle.Transport Instructions between Sites and/or Laboratories:Room TemperatureAdditional Notes:Reference Ranges:  Male:      60—285 U/L  Female: 40—200 U/L

collection:
CK should be used only in the early stages of myocardial infarction. If the CK is normal shortly after onset of chest pain thought to be of myocardial origin then a repeat estimation 3—4 hours later may be helpful.
CK is less sensitive and less specific for the diagnosis of myocardial injury than Troponin I. Skeletal muscle CK is elevated in several situations, e.g. post–operatively, after intramuscular injections, following trauma or vigorous exercise, and in some diseases of skeletal muscle.

row:
Factor IXLaboratory:HaematologyTest Code:F9Specimen Types:PlasmaContainer Types:Sodium CitrateAdults Volume or Mass:2.7 mLCollection & Request Instructions:Specimens cannot be analysed or re-analysed greater than 2 hours after collection.
When the collection is by vacuum tube,the coagulation tube should be collected second to avoid artefactual shortening of coagulation assays due to the trauma of venesection.  When syringes are used, have ready two plastic syringes. A butterfly needle may be used. Withdraw 5 mL blood into the first syringe and discard the syringe (or use it for other tests). With the second syringe, withdraw the required amount of blood for the coagulation tests. When blood is collected from an arterial line it is necessary to discard the first 20mL of blood to clear any heparin from the line before collecting the blood for coagulation tests.Transport Instructions between Sites and/or Laboratories:Room TemperatureAdditional Notes:Reference Range: 50-150%

When the collection is by vacuum tube,the coagulation tube should be collected second to avoid artefactual shortening of coagulation assays due to the trauma of venesection.  When syringes are used, have ready two plastic syringes. A butterfly needle may be used. Withdraw 5 mL blood into the first syringe and discard the syringe (or use it for other tests). With the second syringe, withdraw the required amount of blood for the coagulation tests. When blood is collected from an arterial line it is necessary to discard the first 20mL of blood to clear any heparin from the line before collecting the blood for coagulation tests.Transport Instructions between Sites and/or Laboratories:Room TemperatureAdditional Notes:Reference Range: 50-150 %

row:
CA-125Laboratory:Clinical BiochemistryTest Code:CA125Specimen Types:SerumPlasmaContainer Types:SSTLithium Heparin (with Gel)Collection & Request Instructions:Ca-125 should only be used for follow up of patients with histologically proven tumour and not for screening for cancer. Ca-125 is currently the best serum marker for epithelial ovarian cancer and helpful in the followup and monitoring of these patients..

Indications for measurement of Ca-125 include:


	Staging of newly diagnosed disease
	Surveillance for recurrent disease after curative treatment
	Monitoring of response of disease to treatment


Ca 125 levels may also be elevated in a variety of situations where the peritoneal epithelium is irritated, such as ascites and are therefore not diagnostic of ovarian cancer.

 Transport Instructions between Sites and/or Laboratories:Room TemperatureAdditional Notes:Reference Range:  <35 kU/L

Method used is Abbott Alinity (CMIA).

row:
CEAAlternative Names:Carcinoembryonic AntigenLaboratory:Clinical BiochemistryTest Code:CEASpecimen Types:SerumPlasmaContainer Types:SSTLithium Heparin (with Gel)Collection & Request Instructions:CEA should only be used for follow up of patients with histologically proven tumour and not for screening for cancer. CEA can be elevated in almost any advanced adenocarcinoma but is rarely elevated in localised cancer. It is elevated in a number of non-malignant conditions including chronic liver disease, Crohn’s disease, renal disease, emphysema and in healthy smokers.

Possible clinical indications for measurement are:


	Preoperatively to provide prognostic information, and to assess utility for postoperative surveillance.
	Surveillance following curative resection of colorectal cancer.
	Monitoring therapy for advanced colorectal cancer.


However, there is little evidence that monitoring patients leads to improved outcomes or improved quality of life.Transport Instructions between Sites and/or Laboratories:Room TemperatureAdditional Notes:Reference Range:  < 3.0 ug/L

The upper limit of the reference range is 5.0 ug/L in otherwise-normal smokers.

Method: Abbott Alinity (CMIA).

P1NPAlternative Names:Procollagen type 1 amino-terminal peptideLaboratory:Clinical BiochemistryTest Code:P1NPSpecimen Types:PlasmaSerumContainer Types:EDTA 6 mLSSTLithium Heparin (with Gel)Collection & Request Instructions:Marker of bone formation. Useful for monitoring effect of anti-resorptive therapy and patient compliance.

 

Note: For retrospective test requests;

Serum , K3-EDTA plasma and  Li-heparin plasma are stable for 24 hrs at 15 -25 C, 5 days at 2 - 8C,   6 months at -20C. Samples may be frozen and thawed up to 5 times without adverse effects.

K3-EDTA plasma is our preferred specimen.Transport Instructions between Sites and/or Laboratories:Room TemperatureAssay Frequency:WeekdaysAdditional Notes:REFERENCE INTERVALS

P1NP – Serum procollagen type 1 amino-terminal propeptide

			Age
			
			
			Reference intervals: ug/L
			
		
		
			
			6 – <12 months
			
			
			840-1800

			2 - <3yrs
			
			
			400-1150
			
		
		
			
			3 – <6 yrs
			
			
			300-900
			
		
		
			
			6 – <11 yrs
			
			
			410 - 1020
			
		
		
			
			11 - < 12 yrs
			
			
			110 - 1450
			
		
		
			
			12 –< 15 yrs
			
			
			110 - 1350
			
		
		
			
			15 - < 16yrs

row:
Troponin IAlternative Names:TnILaboratory:Clinical BiochemistryTest Code:TROPONINSpecimen Types:SerumPlasmaContainer Types:SSTLithium Heparin (with Gel)Collection & Request Instructions:Retrospective testing within 7 daysFrom 2/7/2013 Cardiac Troponin I is measured with the Abbott Architect high sensitvity assay with improved low end precision. The units have changed from ug/L to ng/L, giving troponin I values 1000-fold higher than previously. Gender specific 99th percentiles are <27ng/L for men and <17 ng/L for women. Elevated troponin I is indicative of myocardial injury but does not identify the aetiology. Higher troponin I values even below the 99th percentile are associated with worse long term (years) outcome.

 Transport Instructions between Sites and/or Laboratories:Room TemperatureAdditional Notes:Reference Range: Males     < 27 ng/L
                            Females < 17 ng/L

Elevated levels associated with cardiac disease are an independent predictor of mortality.

 

A persistent elevation of Troponin I which is not consistent with the clinical picture can be due to heterophile antibodies interference. Please contact the laboratory for further tests to exclude this interference.

row:
Tricyclic Antidepressant ScreenLaboratory:Clinical BiochemistryTest Code:TCASpecimen Types:SerumPlasmaContainer Types:SSTLithium Heparin (with Gel)Collection & Request Instructions:Screening for Tricyclic Antidepressants in human serum or plasma

Tricyclics are widely used for the treatment of depression and also in the treatment of chronic pain.  Tricyclic overdoses are sometimes used to try to commit suicide.  In this setting, cardiac arrhythmia, respiratory depression and death may result.  Despite a change in the epidemiology of intentional antidepressant overdoses Amitriptyline and similar Tricyclics are continuing to be one of the major causes of death in intentional overdose (Sinyor M, Howlett A, Cheung AH, Schaffer A. Substances used in completed suicide by overdose in Toronto: an observational study of coroner's data. Can J Psychiatry. 2012 Mar;57(3):184-91, Gallagher LM, Kappatos D, Tisch C, Ellis PM. Suicide by poisoning in New Zealand--a toxicological analysis. N Z Med J. 2012 Sep 21;125(1362):15-25).  With levels greater than 500mg/L the incident of serious cardiac toxicity increases significantly (Simpson GM, Pi EH, White K. Plasma drug levels and clinical response to antidepressants. J Clin Psychiatry. 1983 May;44(5 Pt 2):27-34).

The Abbott Alinity Tricyclic Antidepressant assay (TCA) detects a number of tricyclics such as Amitriptyline, Chlorpromazine, Cyclobenzaprine, Desimipramine, Doxepin, Imipramine and Protriptyline. Different drugs are detected by this method to a varying degree. After consultation Clinical Biochemistry has decided that TCA results are reported as  Detected for TCA levels that are greater than 300mg/L (based on nortriptyline).  A Detected result in this assay indicates only the presence of a Tricyclic and does not necessarily correlate with the extent of physiological or psychological effects. If clinically indicated, Detected results should be confirmed by more specific methods such as HPLC or LC Tandem MS.

Hans SchneiderTransport Instructions between Sites and/or Laboratories:Room TemperatureNote:   TCA screen is  QUALITATIVE  only.

Individual TCA levels are not measured at Alfred Pathology.Assay Frequency:24/7Additional Notes:Method: Abbott Alinity for blood tricyclic antidepressants (qualitative). Levels of greater than 300 ug/L are reported as Detected. Levels below 300 ug/L will be reported as Not detected

CYCLOSPORIN THERAPEUTIC RANGES

These ranges are valid from the 8th Jan 2010 using LCMSMS technology.

Cyclosporin levels in μg/L recommended trough (pre – dose)


	
		
			
			Transplant Type
			
			
			< 3 months

			6 – 12 months
			
			
			> 12 months
			
		
		
			
			Heart

			110 – 200
			
			
			80 – 110
			
		
		
			
			Lung
			
			
			225 – 300
			
			
			190 – 260
			
			
			190 – 260
			
			
			150 – 225
			
		
		
			
			Kidney*
			
			
			80 – 150
			
			
			80 – 150
			
			
			60 – 150
			
			
			60 – 150
			
		
		
			
			Bone Marrow
			
			
			80 – 225
			
			
			80 – 225
			
			
			 
			
			
			 
			
		
	


 

Cyclosporin levels recommended 2 Hr post – dose (C2)


	
		
			
			Transplant Type
			
			
			< 3 months
			
			
			3 – 6 months
			
			
			6 – 12 months
			
			
			> 12 months
			
		
		
			
			Heart
			
			
			750 – 1000
			
			
			450 – 750
			
			
			450 – 750
			
			
			300 – 600
			
		
		
			
			Lung
			
			
			600 – 1100
			
			
			530 – 900
			
			
			450 – 700
			
			
			450 – 600
			
		
		
			
			Kidney*
			
			
			750 – 1000
			
			
			600 –750
			
			
			400 – 600
			
			
			400 – 600
			
		
	


 


	NB: For Kidney Transplantation C2 is preferred.


 

Note: No information is available as to the desired range when the drug is used as an immuno-suppressive agent for auto-immune or similar conditions.

 

 

(Reference Range Source: Developed in consultation with The Alfred Transplantation Units and A/Prof. H-G Schneider, Alfred Pathology Service, 2010).

25-Hydroxyvitamin DAlternative Names:Vitamin DVitamin D3Vitamin D -25(OH)Laboratory:Clinical BiochemistryTest Code:25OHVITDSpecimen Types:PlasmaSerumContainer Types:Lithium Heparin (with Gel)SSTTransport Instructions between Sites and/or Laboratories:Room TemperatureAssay Frequency:DailyAdditional Notes:Reference Intervals;

Vitamin D adequacy: > 50 nmol/L at the end of winter (level may need to be 10–20 nmol/L higher at the end of summer, to allow for seasonal decrease).

• Mild vitamin D deficiency: 30–49 nmol/L

• Moderate vitamin deficiency: 12.5–29 nmol/L

• Severe vitamin D deficiency: < 12.5 nmol/L

 

(Ref: Med J Aust 2012; 196 (11): 686-687)

Note: > 250 nmol/L can be associated with toxicity and hypercalcemia.

row:
GlucoseAlternative Names:Random Blood GlucoseFasting Blood GlucoseLaboratory:Clinical BiochemistryTest Code:GL or GLFO or GLFOFSpecimen Types:PlasmaSerumContainer Types:Fluoride OxalateLithium Heparin (with Gel)SSTCollection & Request Instructions:Fluoride Oxalate is the preferred sample where testing will be delayed and/or a diagnostic decision is required. For routine monitoring on inpatients serum is suitable.

Retrospective testing only available on  Fluoride Oxalate sample .Transport Instructions between Sites and/or Laboratories:Room TemperatureAdditional Notes:Reference Intervals:
  Fasting:     3.5 - 6.0 mmol/L
  Random:   3.5 - 7.7  mmol/L

Relevant Ref. Intervals effective from 06/06/2013

 

A random glucose > 7.8 mmol/L in inpatients should trigger clinicians to follow the guideline for  “Blood Glucose Monitoring" (Fig 1) in Alfred Health PROMPT.

 

Comments for Glucose for Pathology Handbook

 

 

Blood glucose values vary normally throughout the day especially between pre- and post-prandial levels.  Normal fasting glucose levels are between 3.5 and 6.0 mmol/L, but levels between 5.5 and 6.0 mmol/L indicate an increased risk for diabetes especially for patients designated as high risk for diabetes: people of Aboriginal, Torres Strait Islander, Maori descent, Pacific Islander people, people from the Indian sub-continent, or of Chinese descent aged 35 and over, all people aged 45 or over who have either obesity or hypertension, all people aged 55 and over, and some others (see Joint Position Statement of RCPA and AACB 2008).  

 

Fasting Glucose Levels ≥ 6.1 to 6.9 mmol/L inclusive are defined as impaired fasting glucose and levels of 7 mmol/L and above define diabetes (if asymptomatic should be confirmed with second specimen). An abnormal level of glucose in the absence of diabetes needs to be repeated.

 

Impaired glucose tolerance (IGT, pre diabetes) is defined as values between 7.8 and 11.1 mmol/L at 2h after a 75g glucose load.  Random blood glucose levels ≥ 11.1 mmol/L ( or 2h after a 75g glucose load) on more than one occasion are diagnostic of diabetes.

Beyond the neonatal period hypoglycaemia is defined as glucose levels below 2.5 mmol/L.

Consensus Guidelines now also allow for HbA1c to be used for the diagnosis of Diabetes Mellitus, although it is currently not reimbursed by Medicare (Med J Aust 2012; 197:220-221).

Prof Hans Schneider: 19 August 2013

collection:
The sample should be collected between 15 minutes and 3 hours after the suspected anaphylactic event.

Increased levels of Tryptase can normally be detected up to 3 to 6 hours after the anaphylactic reaction. Levels return to normal within 12—14 hours after release.
transport: See Detailed InformationSeparated serum can be stored at 4 degrees C for 48 hours for transport between labs. For longer periods samples must be frozen and transported frozen.

HIV SerologyLaboratory:MicrobiologyTest Code:HIVSpecimen Types:SerumContainer Types:SSTCollection & Request Instructions:The treating HMO must obtain the patient's consent before conducting this test.
Section 120AC of the Health Act 1958 requires that 

    a competent patient who is tested; and 
    an incompetent patient at the time of testing who subsequently regains capacity, 

must  be counselled by a registered medical practitioner  
 
 
The person counselled must be provided with details of the test conducted, the reasons why the test was conducted, the results of the test and, if the test indicated the presence of an infectious disease, the effects of that disease on an infected person and the risk to public health of the disease. If needed, advice can be sought from the Infectious Diseases Unit at any time regarding counselling of such patients including the implications of positive tests. 
 Transport Instructions between Sites and/or Laboratories:Room Temperature

row:
D-DimerLaboratory:HaematologyTest Code:DDSpecimen Types:PlasmaContainer Types:Sodium CitrateCollection & Request Instructions:Add exactly 2.7 mL of blood & mix by inversion.D-Dimer in Venous Thromboembolism (VTE)

Normal D-Dimer levels (<0.5 mcg/ml FEU.) essentially exclude VTE when the clinical index of suspicion for the VTE is low. However patients with normal D-Dimer levels, but in whom there is a moderate or high clinical suspicion of thrombosis, may warrant further investigations for VTE. Elevation of D-Dimer levels (>/=0.5 mcg/ml FEU.) occurs in some clinical circumstances in addition to VTE. These include liver disease, pregnancy and increasing age. If clinical features are suggestive of venous thrombosis or pulmonary embolism, further investigations are warranted.

 

D-Dimer in Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation (DIC)

Markedly elevated D-Dimer levels ( >/ =10 mcg/ml FEU.) are associated with DIC. Serial measurements and interpretaion in conjunction with other coagulation assays (fibrinogen, APTT and PT- INR) are recommended to monitor DIC

Specimens cannot be analysed or re-analysed greater than 8 hours after collection.

 Transport Instructions between Sites and/or Laboratories:Room TemperatureAssay Frequency:DailyAdditional Notes:Reference Range:  < 0.5 mcg/ml FEU.

Brain Natriuretic PeptideAlternative Names:BNPLaboratory:Clinical BiochemistryTest Code:BNPSpecimen Types:PlasmaContainer Types:EDTA 10 mLCollection & Request Instructions:Note: BNP analysis is performed on EDTA plasma.

No retrospective addons allowed on whole blood samples.

Note: A separate EDTA tube is required for BNP testing.

If requesting both FBE and BNP -1 x 3 mL  and 1 x 10 mL EDTA tubes must be collected and sent to the laboratory for analysis.

(Consult Clinical Biochemistry laboratory senior scientist if further information required)Transport Instructions between Sites and/or Laboratories:Room TemperatureSend to lab immediatelyAdditional Notes:Reference Ranges: <100 ng/L

BNP levels are higher in females and increase with age. The 95th percentile in people with heart failure aged 55-64 years was 160 ng/L

 

From 3.8.2020, the Alfred is moving to NT Pro BNP as the preferred cardiac marker. Should BNP specifically be required, please contact the Chemical Pathologist to discuss.

BNP Requires Chemical Pathologist approval.

Feto-Maternal HaemorrhageAlternative Names:FMHLaboratory:HaematologyTest Code:FMHSpecimen Types:BloodContainer Types:EDTA 3 mLAdults Volume or Mass:3 mLCollection & Request Instructions:Detects foetal cells in maternal circulation via flowcytometry.
Sample should ideally be collected within 2 hours of the sensitizing event and prior to adminsitration of  RhD immunoglobulin.
The test is only available 9-5 Mon- Fri as a routine test. For urgent testing (required within or after hours) the requesting doctor needs to contact the laboratory (63100) who will put them in contact with the appropriate Haematologist to authorise the test. Once authorised via this process staff will assay  urgently.

row:
Lupus Inhibitor ScreenAlternative Names:Lupus Anticoagulant ScreenLaboratory:HaematologyTest Code:LUPINSpecimen Types:PlasmaContainer Types:Sodium CitrateAdults Volume or Mass:2.7 mLCollection & Request Instructions:Add exactly 2.7 mL of blood & mix by inversion.May be associated with arterial/venous thrombosis. May cause prolongation of APTT.

Specimens cannot be analysed or re-analysed greater than 4 hours after collection.

When the collection is by vacuum tube,the coagulation tube should be collected second to avoid artefactual shortening of coagulation assays due to the trauma of venesection.  When syringes are used, have ready two plastic syringes. A butterfly needle may be used. Withdraw 5 mL blood into the first syringe and discard the syringe (or use it for other tests). With the second syringe, withdraw the required amount of blood for the coagulation tests. When blood is collected from an arterial line it is necessary to discard the first 20mL of blood to clear any heparin from the line before collecting the blood for coagulation tests.Transport Instructions between Sites and/or Laboratories:Room Temperature
Test: Lupus Inhibitor ScreenAlternative Names:Lupus Anticoagulant Screen
collection:
Add exactly 2.7 mL of blood & mix by inversion.May be associated with arterial/venous thrombosis. May cause prolongation of APTT.

Specimens cannot be analysed or re-analysed greater than 4 hours after collection.

When the collection is by vacuum tube,the coagulation tube should be collected second to avoid artefactual shortening of coagulation assays due to the trauma of venesection.  When syringes are used, have ready two plastic syringes. A butterfly needle may be used. Withdraw 5 mL blood into the first syringe and discard the syringe (or use it for other tests). With the second syringe, withdraw the required amount of blood for the coagulation tests. When blood is collected from an arterial line it is necessary to discard the first 20mL of blood to clear any heparin from the line before collecting the blood for coagulation tests.
transport:
Lupus Inhibitor ScreenAlternative Names:Lupus Anticoagulant ScreenLaboratory:HaematologyTest Code:LUPINSpecimen Types:PlasmaContainer Types:Sodium CitrateAdults Volume or Mass:2.7 mLCollection & Request Instructions:Add exactly 2.7 mL of blood & mix by inversion.May be associated with arterial/venous thrombosis. May cause prolongation of APTT.

Specimens cannot be analysed or re-analysed greater than 4 hours after collection.

When the collection is by vacuum tube,the coagulation tube should be collected second to avoid artefactual shortening of coagulation assays due to the trauma of venesection.  When syringes are used, have ready two plastic syringes. A butterfly needle may be used. Withdraw 5 mL blood into the first syringe and discard the syringe (or use it for other tests). With the second syringe, withdraw the required amount of blood for the coagulation tests. When blood is collected from an arterial line it is necessary to discard the first 20mL of blood to clear any heparin from the line before collecting the blood for coagulation tests.

Renin AmbulantLaboratory:Clinical BiochemistryTest Code:REN-ASpecimen Types:PlasmaContainer Types:EDTA 3 mLCollection & Request Instructions:Retrospective testing not possible.Endocrine consultation is required in planning renal vein sampling.Transport Instructions between Sites and/or Laboratories:Room TemperatureSend to lab immediately 

If specimens are collected from a location external to Alfred Pathology, they should be spun and the plasma frozen at -80 C. Please note that freezing at -20 C is NOT sufficient and may cause cryo-activation of pro-renin leading to falsely high results.

Once frozen at -80 C, samples can be transferred to, or transported at, -20 C.

 Assay Frequency:Twice weeklyAdditional Notes: 

Reference Interval:  4.4 - 46.1 mIU/L

Source: Diasorin Liaison kit insert 200/007-906,06-2016-04

ARR- aldosterone renin ratio

Aldosterone-Renin Ratio (ARR) is a screening test not a diagnostic test for primary hyperaldosteronism. As of 08/06/2017 Aldosterone and Renin are being performed on the Diasorin Liaison XL platform. Please note changed reference intervals.

An aldosterone-renin ratio cut-off of > 70 should prompt further investigation for primary hyperaldosteronism in the appropriate clinical setting. Lower cut-offs improve sensitivity with a loss in specificity whereas higher cut-offs are more specific for primary hyperaldosteronism (with a concomitant loss in sensitivity).

Reference: The Endocrine Society clinical practice guideline on primary hyperaldosteronism,  Funder JW, Carey RM, Mantero F, et al. J Clin Endocrinol Metab 101:1889-1916, 2016

Note: Renin is measured as direct renin mass (mIU/L) rather than plasma renin activity (µg/L/hr) previously. There is no conversion factor for the two assays. Compared to plasma renin activity, renin mass is reduced in high estrogen states (oral contraceptive pill) and increased in patients taking renin inhibitors.

PIIINPAlternative Names:P3NPLaboratory:Clinical BiochemistryTest Code:P3NPSpecimen Types:SerumPlasmaContainer Types:SSTCollection & Request Instructions:Serum preferred. Lithium Heparin and EDTA plasma acceptable.Transport Instructions between Sites and/or Laboratories:Room TemperatureIf sending samples from outside institutions - please send samples frozen.

Specimen volume required : Absolute minimum 0.6 mL frozen aliquot. Ideally send 1 mL frozen aliquot.Assay Frequency:No Longer AvailableAdditional Notes:Aminoterminal peptide of type III procollagen (PIIINP) is produced in the processing of procollagen to mature collagen type III. This marker has been used to identify patients at increased risk of liver fibrosis who are exposed to large amounts of methotrexate (>1.5g total).

The cut-off level that is used to identify patients at increased risk is > 4.2 ug/L.

Note that this is well within the reference range as described by the company. The reference interval for adults (19 -65 years) was determined in over 200 healthy adults as 2.3 ug/L to 6.4 ug/L.

Reference values in children are significantly higher. Further note that this is the same assay that has been used in the clinical studies published (Maurice PDL et al. Monitoring patients on Methotrexate: hepatic fibrosis not seen in patients with normal serum assays of aminoterminal peptide of type III procollagen. Br J Dermatol 2005; 152:451 - 8, Kahn S et al. Use of amino terminal type III procollagen peptide (P3NP) assay in methotrexate therapy for psoriasis, Postgrad Med J 2006;82:353-354).

Ref. Range details supplied by A/Prof. Hans Schneider November 2008.

NOTE: This test NO longer available at Alfred Pathology Service

The cut-off level that is used to identify patients at increased risk is > 4.2 ug/L.

Note that this is well within the reference range as described by the company. The reference interval for adults (19 -65 years) was determined in over 200 healthy adults as 2.3 ug/L to 6.4 ug/L.

Reference values in children are significantly higher. Further note that this is the same assay that has been used in the clinical studies published (Maurice PDL et al. Monitoring patients on Methotrexate: hepatic fibrosis not seen in patients with normal serum assays of aminoterminal peptide of type III procollagen. Br J Dermatol 2005; 152:451 - 8, Kahn S et al. Use of amino terminal type III procollagen peptide (P3NP) assay in methotrexate therapy for psoriasis, Postgrad Med J 2006;82:353-354).

row:
Pro-Brain Natriuretic PeptideAlternative Names:NTBNPPro-BNPLaboratory:Clinical BiochemistryTest Code:NTBNPSpecimen Types:SerumPlasmaContainer Types:SSTLithium Heparin (with Gel)Adults Volume or Mass:4 mLMinimum/Paediatric Volume or Mass:4 mLTransport Instructions between Sites and/or Laboratories:Room TemperatureAssay Frequency:DailyAdditional Notes: 

 

From 3 August 2020-  NTPro-BNP Assay performed on Abbott Alinity

Reference Intervals:

NTPro-BNP <125ng/L makes a diagnosis of congestive heart failure (CHF) very unlikely1 , while a NTPro-BNP >150ng/L is associated with increased 10 year mortality2.

Optimal sensitivity and specificity cut off for NTPro-BNP in CHF diagnosis in the ED was found with age-adjusted cut offs3,4

Age < 50            >450ng/L

Age 50 -75         >900ng/L

Age >75             >1800ng/L

1) Ponikowski P et al. 2016 ESC Guidelines for the diagnosis and treatment of acute and chronic heart failure.Eur J Heart Fail 2016;18(8):891-975.

2) Taylor CJ et al. The potential role of NT-proBNP in screening for and predicting prognosis in heart failure: a survival analysis. BMJ Open 2014;4:e004675

3) Januzzi JL et al. NT-proBNP testing for diagnosis and short-term prognosis in acute destabilized heart failure: an international pooled analysis of 1256 patients: the International Collaborative of NT-proBNP Study. Eur Heart J. 2006;27(3):330-337.

note:
From 3 August 2020-  NTPro-BNP Assay performed on Abbott Alinity

Reference Intervals:

NTPro-BNP <125ng/L makes a diagnosis of congestive heart failure (CHF) very unlikely1 , while a NTPro-BNP >150ng/L is associated with increased 10 year mortality2.

Optimal sensitivity and specificity cut off for NTPro-BNP in CHF diagnosis in the ED was found with age-adjusted cut offs3,4

Age < 50            >450ng/L

Age 50 -75         >900ng/L

Age >75             >1800ng/L

1) Ponikowski P et al. 2016 ESC Guidelines for the diagnosis and treatment of acute and chronic heart failure.Eur J Heart Fail 2016;18(8):891-975.

2) Taylor CJ et al. The potential role of NT-proBNP in screening for and predicting prognosis in heart failure: a survival analysis. BMJ Open 2014;4:e004675

3) Januzzi JL et al. NT-proBNP testing for diagnosis and short-term prognosis in acute destabilized heart failure: an international pooled analysis of 1256 patients: the International Collaborative of NT-proBNP Study. Eur Heart J. 2006;27(3):330-337.

4) Januzzi JL Jr et al. N-Terminal Pro-B-Type Natriuretic Peptide in the Emergency Department: The ICON-RELOADED Study. J Am Coll Cardiol. 2018;71(11):1191-1200.4)

Parathyroid HormoneAlternative Names:PTHPTH (1-84)Laboratory:Clinical BiochemistryTest Code:PTHSpecimen Types:PlasmaContainer Types:EDTA 10 mLCollection & Request Instructions: 

Note: A separate EDTA tube is required for PTH testing.

If requesting both FBE and PTH - 1  x 3 mL  and 1 x 10 mL EDTA tubes must be collected and sent to the laboratory for analysis.

 

ADD ON requirements- Note-  PTH CANNOT be added on retrospectively.

 

If test required please recollect EDTA specimen.Transport Instructions between Sites and/or Laboratories:Transport samples between laboratories at 4 C in an esky.Assay Frequency:DailyAdditional Notes:Reference Interval:  1.6—6.0 pmol/L

Interpretation depends on serum calcium level, renal function and Vitamin D status.

Source: Roche kit insert: version no. 2016-12,V4.0

Method changed to Roche Elecsys PTH (1-84) from Roche Elecsys iPTH on 8/05/2017.

Note: Changed Reference Interval  

Please contact Prof. Hans Schneider (pager 4367) or Chemical Pathology registrar (pager 5459) for further clarification.

Note: Biotin supplementation may cause falsely low results due to interference with the PTH assay. If the patient is known to be taking Biotin, interpret results with caution and contact the Chemical Pathologist (03) 90763118 if further discussion is required.

row:
Renin RecumbentLaboratory:Clinical BiochemistryTest Code:REN-RSpecimen Types:PlasmaContainer Types:EDTA 3 mLCollection & Request Instructions:Retrospective testing not possible.Patient should be in a recumbent position for 30 minutes prior to, and during the collection.

Endocrine consultation is required in planning renal vein sampling.Transport Instructions between Sites and/or Laboratories:Room TemperatureSend to lab immediately 

If specimens are collected from a location external to Alfred Pathology, they should be spun and the plasma frozen at -80 C. Please note that freezing at -20 C is NOT sufficient and may cause cryo-activation of pro-renin leading to falsely high results.

Once frozen at -80 C, samples can be transferred to, or transported at, -20 C.Assay Frequency:Twice weeklyAdditional Notes:Reference Interval:  2.8 - 39.9 mIU/L

Source: Diasorin Liaison kit insert, 200/007-906,06-2016-04

ARR- aldosterone renin ratio

Aldosterone-Renin Ratio (ARR) is a screening test not a diagnostic test for primary hyperaldosteronism. As of 08/06/2017 Aldosterone and Renin are being performed on the Diasorin Liaison XL platform. Please note changed reference intervals.

An aldosterone-renin ratio cut-off of > 70 should prompt further investigation for primary hyperaldosteronism in the appropriate clinical setting. Lower cut-offs improve sensitivity with a loss in specificity whereas higher cut-offs are more specific for primary hyperaldosteronism (with a concomitant loss in sensitivity).

Reference: The Endocrine Society clinical practice guideline on primary hyperaldosteronism,  Funder JW, Carey RM, Mantero F, et al. J Clin Endocrinol Metab 101:1889-1916, 2016

Note: Renin is measured as direct renin mass (mIU/L) rather than plasma renin activity (µg/L/hr) previously. There is no conversion factor for the two assays. Compared to plasma renin activity, renin mass is reduced in high estrogen states (oral contraceptive pill) and increased in patients taking renin inhibitors.

APTTAlternative Names:Activated Partial Thromboplastin TimeLaboratory:HaematologyTest Code:APTTSpecimen Types:PlasmaContainer Types:Sodium CitrateAdults Volume or Mass:2.7 mLCollection & Request Instructions:Add exactly 2.7 mL of blood & mix by inversion.Deliver to laboratory within 60 minutesWhen the collection is by vacuum tube,the coagulation tube should be collected second to avoid artefactual shortening of coagulation assays due to the trauma of venesection.  When syringes are used, have ready two plastic syringes. A butterfly needle may be used. Withdraw 5 mL blood into the first syringe and discard the syringe (or use it for other tests). With the second syringe, withdraw the required amount of blood for the coagulation tests. When blood is collected from an arterial line it is necessary to discard the first 20mL of blood to clear any heparin from the line before collecting the blood for coagulation tests.

This test is insensitive to therapeutic doses of Low Molecular Weight Heparin (see ANTI-Xa ASSAY and ANTICOAGULANT THERAPY CONTROL).

APTT may be artefactually shortened if the venesection is traumatic or artefactually prolonged if the tube is 'under-filled' or the patient has a raised haemoglobin/haematocrit.

Specimens cannot be analysed or re-analysed greater than 2 hours after collection.Transport Instructions between Sites and/or Laboratories:Room Temperature___Transport within 1 hour post collection.Additional Notes:Reference Range:  26.0—38.0 sec

IV Heparin Therapeutic Range:  52-94 sec (in-house validation against heparin anti-Xa October 2014)
collection:
Add exactly 2.7 mL of blood & mix by inversion.Deliver to laboratory within 60 minutesWhen the collection is by vacuum tube,the coagulation tube should be collected second to avoid artefactual shortening of coagulation assays due to the trauma of venesection.  When syringes are used, have ready two plastic syringes. A butterfly needle may be used. Withdraw 5 mL blood into the first syringe and discard the syringe (or use it for other tests). With the second syringe, withdraw the required amount of blood for the coagulation tests. When blood is collected from an arterial line it is necessary to discard the first 20mL of blood to clear any heparin from the line before collecting the blood for coagulation tests.

This test is insensitive to therapeutic doses of Low Molecular Weight Heparin (see ANTI-Xa ASSAY and ANTICOAGULANT THERAPY CONTROL).

APTT may be artefactually shortened if the venesection is traumatic or artefactually prolonged if the tube is 'under-filled' or the patient has a raised haemoglobin/haematocrit.

Specimens cannot be analysed or re-analysed greater than 2 hours after collection.

Ionised CalciumAlternative Names:Calcium; IonisedLaboratory:Clinical BiochemistryTest Code:ICASpecimen Types:SerumContainer Types:SSTCollection & Request Instructions:Specimen must not be exposed to air. Supply either a separate, full serum container or a venous or arterial specimen collected in a syringe as for Blood Gases. 
Mix well and deliver immediately.
Note: Syringes containing 125 USP units of heparin are unsuitable due to binding of ionised calcium.

This test may be of value when doubt exists about calcium status in the presence of hypoalbuminaemia and in acid/base disturbances.
Stasis must be avoided when taking blood as prolonged use of a torniquet gives falsely high values, as does haemolysis.Transport Instructions between Sites and/or Laboratories:Room TemperatureAdditional Notes:Reference Range:  1.11—1.28mmol/L
Ionised Calcium Reference Range change from 1/7/10.
Data established in APS lab (n=70 healthy adults). HGS.

This is not the correct test for NPM1-MRD (minimal residual disease).

Pneumococcal AntibodiesLaboratory:MicrobiologyTest Code:PNANSpecimen Types:SerumContainer Types:SSTAdults Volume or Mass:1 mLCollection & Request Instructions:Pre and Post vaccination sera required. Send second serum approximately 6 weeks post vaccination.

The pre serum will be stored for a maximum of 6 months awaiting the post serum.

Instruct patients to return to the same collection centre so that specimen matching can occur.

Serum from splenectomy patients will be sent on receipt. Indicate clearly on the request slip.

 Transport Instructions between Sites and/or Laboratories:Room TemperaturePre serum sent only on request.

Pre and post sera are sent together for testing in parallel.External Laboratory:Women's and Children's Pathology Services, RCH

A maximum of  1 CMV viral load test per sample type will be performed on any patient in a one week period. 
Requests for urgent or more frequent testing must be approved by the Microbiology Unit Head. 
Transport Instructions between Sites and/or Laboratories:Room TemperatureAssay Frequency:Weekly

row: Prothrombin G20210A MutationAlternative Names:Prothrombin GenePT GeneG20210APTGMLaboratory:Human MolecularTest Code:PT GENESpecimen Types:BloodContainer Types:EDTA 3 mLAdults Volume or Mass:3 mLCollection & Request Instructions:For identification of carriers of inherited venous thrombophilia. General population screening and routine screening before prescribing oral contraceptives or hormone replacement therapy are not recommended. row:
CSF Xanthochromia ScreenAlternative Names:CSF BilirubinXanthochromiaLaboratory:Clinical BiochemistryTest Code:CSXANSpecimen Types:Cerebrospinal FluidContainer Types:CSF Tube 4CSF Tube 3Collection & Request Instructions:Spinal tap should be performed at least 12hrs following suspected SAH.

Send to laboratory Urgently - must be spun within 1hr.

Tube 4 is the preferred tube.

Cover sample with foil to protect from light.Transport Instructions between Sites and/or Laboratories:Room TemperatureAdditional Notes:Please note - if the sample is received after being unprotected from light this can lead to a decrease in bilirubin and a false negative result for Xanthochromia. Please interpret with this in mind and in the context of other tests and clinical history.

Reference: Foroughi M, Parikh D, Wassell J, Hatfield R. Influence of light and time on bilirubin degradation in CSF spectrophotometry for subarachnoid haemorrhage. Br J Neurosurg. 2010 Aug;24(4):401-4”

row:
CSF Oligoclonal BandsAlternative Names:Oligoclonal IgG (CSF)IgG/Albumin ratio CSFIsoelectric Focussing CSFLaboratory:Clinical BiochemistryTest Code:CSIEFSpecimen Types:Cerebrospinal FluidContainer Types:CSF Tube 1Adults Volume or Mass:0.5 mLCollection & Request Instructions:Serum sample must be collected at the same time for interpretation of results.
Retrospective testing with 7 days.Transport Instructions between Sites and/or Laboratories:Room TemperatureAdditional Notes:In several diseases of the central nervous system (multiple sclerosis and certain chronic infectious diseases such as sub–acute sclerosing pan–encephalitis and neurosyphilis) there are quantitative and qualitative alterations in immunoglobulins synthesised inside the blood–brain barrier. A relative increase in IgG in CSF, compared with serum, and the existence of oligoclonal bands (discrete bands representing IgG molecules of restricted heterogeneity) in CSF, which do not exist in serum at that time, provide strong evidence for the diagnosis of multiple sclerosis.

note: In several diseases of the central nervous system (multiple sclerosis and certain chronic infectious diseases such as sub–acute sclerosing pan–encephalitis and neurosyphilis) there are quantitative and qualitative alterations in immunoglobulins synthesised inside the blood–brain barrier. A relative increase in IgG in CSF, compared with serum, and the existence of oligoclonal bands (discrete bands representing IgG molecules of restricted heterogeneity) in CSF, which do not exist in serum at that time, provide strong evidence for the diagnosis of multiple sclerosis.

Test by appointment only, following consultation with laboratory haematology medical staff. Assay only valid if platelet count is adequate( >100 x 10 9/L) in most cases. Request should include information on bleeding history and medication.

Specimens cannot be analysed or re-analysed greater than 4 hours after collection.

2.7 mL of blood is drawn into six (6) sodium citrate vacuum tubes.  These are kept at room temperature and sent to the laboratory asap.

 Transport Instructions between Sites and/or Laboratories:Room TemperatureSend to lab immediatelyAdditional Notes:2.7 mL of blood is drawn into six (6) sodium citrate vacuum tubes.  These are kept at room temperature and sent to the laboratory asap.

row:
Urine Microscopy & CultureAlternative Names:Urine CultureLaboratory:MicrobiologyTest Code:URI CSpecimen Types:Urine MidstreamUrine CatheterContainer Types:Sterile ContainerPlain 70mL potMinimum/Paediatric Volume or Mass:10 mLCollection & Request Instructions:Male Patients: The foreskin should be gently retracted and the glans cleaned with cotton wool and sterile water. Do not use soap or disinfectants. When urinary stream is well established obtain 10-20 mL in a container.

Female Patients: The labia must be separated and washed with cotton wool and sterile water from front to back. A vaginal tampon is useful if there is vaginal discharge. Better results will be obtained if the patient is carefully instructed and then allowed to collect the specimen herself, rather than trying to collect the urine with the patient in bed.

Indwelling Catheters: Urine must not be obtained from the bag, but by sterile syringe from the catheter tubing which has been temporarily clipped off.

Red cell morphology must be specifically requested.  Mark specimen urgent and send immediately to the laboratory. This test is only available between 0800 and 1700.

From 1st April 2010, routine “Dipstick” testing will no longer be performed on urine samples.

 

Testing will however be performed when specifically requested.  Orders for dipsticks should clearly state “dipstick test” in addition to urine microscopy and culture.

 Transport Instructions between Sites and/or Laboratories:Use Esky from SDMH or CGMC to AlfredRefrigerate at 4 degrees if delayed. Send promptly to laboratory.Additional Notes:Interpretation:

Cell count:
>10 x 106/L white cells suggests infection;
>10 x 106/L red blood cells indicates haematuria;
presence of dysmorphic red cells indicates glomerular origin;
Squamous epithelial cells indicate skin/mucosal contamination of the sample.

Faeces CultureAlternative Names:Clostridium difficile cultureCampylobacter cultureSalmonella cultureShigella cultureLaboratory:MicrobiologyTest Code:FAE CSpecimen Types:FaecesContainer Types:Faecal Collection KitAdults Volume or Mass:10 gCollection & Request Instructions: Investigations for Salmonella, Shigella and Campylobacter are restricted to Outpatients and patients hospitalised for less than 4 days.

Only one (1) faecal sample is required. Collect 10g of faeces into each container.

Culture for Clostridium difficile is performed only on loose or watery stools.

Relevant clinical notes are essential. A history of recent overseas travel must be documented on the request slip.

Rectal swabs are unsuitable unless the patient is in ICU. For further information, contact the Microbiology Registrar.Transport Instructions between Sites and/or Laboratories:Room Temperature

FoetoMaternal HaemorrhageAlternative Names:Kleihauer TestLaboratory:HaematologyTest Code:FMHSpecimen Types:BloodContainer Types:EDTA 3 mLAdults Volume or Mass:3 mLCollection & Request Instructions:Maternal sample only.
Detects foetal cells in the maternal circulation.
The test will be available Monday to Friday 9am—5pm and at other times by consultation with the Laboratory Haematologist on call. To quantify FMH using Flow Cytometry identification of maternal and infant blood groups is mandatory so the correct assay can be performed. Please include details of infant's UR number and date of birth in the Clinical Notes area of the request form.Transport Instructions between Sites and/or Laboratories:Room Temperature

row:
Pus CultureLaboratory:MicrobiologyTest Code:SUNDRY CSpecimen Types:AspirateFluidContainer Types:Sterile ContainerCollection & Request Instructions:Aspirate from collection, abscess or wound; biopsy of abscess wall. The specimen should be collected in a sterile container. It is also possible to send a capped syringe (needle must be removed). 
Pus should always be aspirated, if possible, rather than collecting a wound swab.
Swabs from a draining wound or sinus are frequently contaminated with normal flora from skin, mucous membrane.
Pus should be transported immediately to the laboratory.
Biopsy of abscess wall or adjacent tissue may increase the yield, especially in chronic infection.Transport Instructions between Sites and/or Laboratories:Room Temperature

row:
Cortisol; Dynamic testingAlternative Names:Synacthen TestDexamethasone TestLaboratory:Clinical BiochemistryTest Code:VariousSpecimen Types:BloodContainer Types:See Detailed InformationCollection & Request Instructions:Endocrine consultation is suggested for dynamic testing. e.g. Short/Long Stimulation or Suppression tests using Synacthen or Dexamethasone. For details of clinical indications, test performance and clinical significance of changes see document link below or consult Endocrinology.

Dynamic Testing

All samples must be clearly marked with patient identification, time and date of sample. Sampling times must also be clearly written on request form.Transport Instructions between Sites and/or Laboratories:See Detailed InformationAdditional Notes:
	
		
			
			 
			
			
			Short Synacthen Test (SST)

			A normal response is a 30 minute post synacthen cortisol value of 430 nmol/L in males,      420 nmol/L in females (over 580 nmol/L in women on oral contraceptives). El-Farhan et al. Clin Endocrinol (2013) 78, 673–680. 

			Additional Notes: 60 minute values are about 15% higher.

			NB A basal cortisol of 340 nmol/L had a 100% specificity for a normal short synacthen test, therefore SST is not needed. Sbardella et al. Clin Endocrinol (2017) 86, 177-184.

row: Leucocyte ImmunophenotypingAlternative Names:FACSFlow cytometryLaboratory:HaematologyTest Code:SMSpecimen Types:BloodBone MarrowTissueCerebrospinal FluidFluidContainer Types:EDTA 3 mLFresh Tissue PotAdults Volume or Mass:3 mLCollection & Request Instructions:Flow Cytometric analysis of cells stained with a range of antibodies against lymphoid and myeloid markers. The panel of markers used will be appropriate to the clinical notes supplied or as arranged by prior consultation. Samples must be marked "Urgent", must reach the laboratory as soon as possible, and will not normally be accepted after 5pm Monday - Friday. All out-of hours testing requires notification to the on call Laboratory Haematologist (via switch) and the laboratory (x62468). An FBE must also be requested and collected (additional 3mL EDTA tube)) if Leucocyte Immunophenotyping is requested on peripheral blood.Transport Instructions between Sites and/or Laboratories:Send to lab immediatelyAssay Frequency:Weekdays

Fluid Cell Count and CultureAlternative Names:Ascitic fluidPleural fluidPD fluidsynovial fluidLaboratory:MicrobiologyTest Code:FLU CSpecimen Types:FluidContainer Types:Sterile ContainerLithium Heparin (without Gel)Collection & Request Instructions:Examination for mycobacteria are performed only on specific request.
Ascitic, Synovial, Pleural Fluids are often clotted on arrival and only a qualitative count and Gram stain are performed.
Synovial Fluids are routinely examined for crystals.  Mark request slip URGENT.
Add 1-2mL of fluid to a lithium heparin tube to prevent the specimen clotting. Fluids in blood tubes are unsuitable for culture. 
Peritoneal Dialysate should be sent in a sterile container for cell count and culture.
Send 40 mL of fluid in a sterile container. Do not send bags.
 Transport Instructions between Sites and/or Laboratories:Room Temperature

row:
QuantiFERON®-TB KitAlternative Names:Interferon-Gamma assay for Mycobacterium tuberculosisM.tuberculosis Interferon-Gamma assayLaboratory:MicrobiologyTest Code:QUANTTBSpecimen Types:BloodContainer Types:QuantiFERON TB 4 tube setCollection & Request Instructions:The blood collection tubes supplied are for use only with the QuantiFERON®-TB system (QFT®). The following instructions relate solely to the use of QFT® blood collection tubes.

Antigens have been dried onto the inner wall of the blood collection tubes so it is essential that the contents of the tubes be thoroughly mixed with the blood. The tubes must be transferred to a 37oC incubator as soon as possible and within 16 hours of collection.

 

 Note: Samples should reach the laboratory by 1600 Monday to Friday for timely processing. 

Collection of these samples on weekends or public holidays is strongly discouraged.

The following procedures should be followed for optimal results:

 

Blood Collection:

For each subject collect 1mL of blood by venipuncture directly into each of the QFT® blood collection tubes.

Order of draw:

1. Grey (nil) tube

2. Green (TB1 antigen) tube

3. Yellow (TB2 antigen) tube

4. Purple (mitogen) tube·

 

 As 1mL tubes draw blood relatively slowly, keep the tube on the needle for 2-3 seconds once the tube appears to have completed filling, to ensure that the correct volume is drawn.

The black mark on the side of the tubes indicates the validated range of 0.8 to 1.2 mL. If the level of blood in any tube is outside the range of the indicator mark, another blood sample should be obtained..

If a “butterfly needle” is used, prime tubing with a “purge” tube before filling the QFT® tubes.

Mix by vigorously shaking the tubes up and down 10 times to ensure that the entire inner surface of the tube has been coated with the blood.

Thorough mixing is required to ensure complete integration of the tube’s contents into the blood.

 

Label tubes appropriately.Transport Instructions between Sites and/or Laboratories:Room TemperatureAssay Frequency:Twice weekly

Chlamydia trachomatis &/or Neisseria gonorrhoeae PCRAlternative Names:Chlamydia PCRChlamydia & Gonorrheoa PCRGonorrhoea PCRLaboratory:MicrobiologyTest Code:CGPCR, GONOPCR, CTRPCRSpecimen Types:Urine First CatchSwabContainer Types:Plain 70mL potCobas PCR media Uni Swab Sample kitCollection & Request Instructions:This test is available on the following specimens:            


	Urine (10 - 20 mL of first pass urine)
	Endocervical swabs
	Vaginal swabs  
	Eye swabs
	Rectal swabs
	Urethral swabs
	Throat swabs


Swabs specimens must be collected using the Cobas PCR media Uni swab sample kit which is available from Central Specimen Processing in Pathology.

For N. gonorrhoeae investigation from eye or throat swabs, culture is recommended. A separate elution swab is essential for this test. Indicate gonorrhoea culture is required on the request form.

 

 Transport Instructions between Sites and/or Laboratories:Room TemperatureAssay Frequency:3 x weekly (thrice)

row:
Herpes Virus Multiplex PCRAlternative Names:HSV-1 PCRHSV-2 PCRCMV PCR (not viral load)VZV PCRVaricella Zoster PCRViral PCR for Herpes virusesSwab for Herpes PCRAdenovirus PCREnterovirus PCRLaboratory:MicrobiologyTest Code:Herpes Adenovirus Enterovirus PCR, HERPPCRSpecimen Types:SwabTissueCerebrospinal FluidPlasmaContainer Types:See Under Collection InstructionsCSF Tube 3EDTA 10 mLCollection & Request Instructions:For quantitative CMV PCR order CMV Viral Load.

A separate EDTA blood tube is essential. It cannot be used for other tests.

Use a blue capped elution swab (eSwab) for collection.  These are purchased using eReq.

Guidelines for swab collection.

A sterile flocked swab is used to vigorously swab the base of the lesion— applying enough pressure to collect epithelial cells without causing bleeding—and collect vesicular fluid. It is important to collect infected epithelial cells from the base of the lesion because they usually contain a significant amount of virus. 
Break off the swab in the amies transport medium accompanying the swab.

For investigation of CMV colitis, a colonic biopsy is recommended. For all other enquires, please contact the Microbiology Registrar.Transport Instructions between Sites and/or Laboratories:Room TemperatureAssay Frequency:WeekdaysAdditional Notes:Viruses screened in this PCR are HSV-1, HSV-2, CMV,  VZV, Enterovirus and Adenovirus.

row:
Ova, cysts and parasitesAlternative Names:ParasitesOCPStrongyloides stercoralis cultureFaeces ova cysts and parasitesSchistosoma haematobium investigation (urine)PinwormEnterobius vermicularisLaboratory:MicrobiologyTest Code:OCPSpecimen Types:FaecesAspirateUrine randomSee Under Collection InstructionsContainer Types:Faecal Collection KitPlain 70mL potAdults Volume or Mass:10 gCollection & Request Instructions:Investigations for ova, cysts and parasites are restricted to Outpatients and patients hospitalised for less than 4 days.

See separate entry for cryptosporidium or cyclospora stains. These tests must be requested separately.

Only one (1) faecal sample is required. It must be placed in the fixative contained in the faecal collection kit available from the laboratory.

Strongyloides culture

Pathologist approval is required for Strongyloides stercoralis culture. Phone the laboratory for special collection instructions. Specimens must be labelled URGENT and arrive in Microbiology within 1 hour of collection between 0800 and 1630. Do not refrigerate.

Duodenal aspirates must arrive in Microbiology within 1 hour of collection. Mark specimens URGENT. Do not refrigerate.

For Schistosoma haematobium in urine, collection of a whole void specimen taken anytime between 12 noon and 3pm in a container without preservatives is recommended. Peak egg excretion is between noon and 3 p.m.

 

 Mark specimens URGENT.

Enterobius vermicularis (Pinworm)

The specimen should be obtained in the morning before showering or using the toilet. Take about 3 cm of transparent cellulose (sticky tape). With the sticky side outwards, press frimly against the perianal and perineal skin. Place the tape in a sealed specimen container. Eggs adhere to the cellulose tape and can be detected microscopically in the laboratory.Transport Instructions between Sites and/or Laboratories:RoomTemp within Alfred/Esky from External sitesAssay Frequency:WeekdaysAdditional Notes:The presence of urine, kaolin, magnesia, bismuth, barium, antibiotics, antihelminthics or antiprotozoal substances may interfere with the detection of parasites in faeces.

Swab for culture - woundAlternative Names:Wound cultureLaboratory:MicrobiologyTest Code:WOU CSpecimen Types:SwabContainer Types:eSwab (Elution swab)Collection & Request Instructions:Swabs with liquid transport medium are essential for anaerobes or when a delay in testing is expected e.g. after hours.

The type of wound and site of origin is essential for interpretation of culture results. eg abscess/left arm, cat bite/right hand. Relevant clinical information should be recorded.

 Use a swab moistened with sterile saline to clean the wound then firmly sample the margin. 

 

 Transport Instructions between Sites and/or Laboratories:Room TemperatureAssay Frequency:Daily

row:
Respiratory PCRAlternative Names:Influenza PCRParainfluenza PCRRSV PCRAdenovirus PCR (respiratory)Human Metapneumovirus PCRPicornavirus PCRViral PCR for respiratory virusesSwab for respiratory viruses PCRLaboratory:MicrobiologyTest Code:Respiratory PCR, RESPPCR, RESPPCRASpecimen Types:SwabBronchoalveolar LavageBronchial WashingsSputumContainer Types:Viral Transport MediumPlain 70mL potCollection & Request Instructions:Viral transport medium swabs are available from Pathology Central Specimen Processing.

Rapid testing for Influenza A, Influenza B and RSV is performed on all specimens. 

Reflex testing using the extended respiratory virus PCR panel will be performed on samples that are negative for the rapid influenza/RSV test on the following patients:


	ICU patients
	Patients in 5 East
	Lung transplant patients, where this is clearly stated in the clinical notes.
	Cystic fibrosis patients, where this is clearly stated in the clinical notes.
	All BAL samples.
	Clinical Haematology patients in 7 East and 7 West


If extended respiratory virus PCR is required on patients who do not fit these criteria, discussion with the Medical Microbiologist is required. Add-ons via request slip without prior consultation will not be accepted.

Refer to the Alfred Health guideline "Management of Seasonal Influenza" for instructions to collect nose/throat swabs.

Mouth swabs are not an acceptable specimen.Transport Instructions between Sites and/or Laboratories:RoomTemp within Alfred/Esky from External sitesAssay Frequency:WeekdaysAdditional Notes:The following respiratory pathogens are detected with the extended panel: Influenza A/B, Parainfluenza 1,2,3, RSV, Adenovirus, Human Metapneumovirus, Rhinovirus/Enterovirus, Bordetella pertussis and Mycoplasma pneumoniae.

Turn around time for the extended panel is 36 to 48 hours (longer over weekends).

collection:
Viral transport medium swabs are available from Pathology Central Specimen Processing.

Rapid testing for Influenza A, Influenza B and RSV is performed on all specimens. 

Reflex testing using the extended respiratory virus PCR panel will be performed on samples that are negative for the rapid influenza/RSV test on the following patients:


	ICU patients
	Patients in 5 East
	Lung transplant patients, where this is clearly stated in the clinical notes.
	Cystic fibrosis patients, where this is clearly stated in the clinical notes.
	All BAL samples.
	Clinical Haematology patients in 7 East and 7 West


If extended respiratory virus PCR is required on patients who do not fit these criteria, discussion with the Medical Microbiologist is required. Add-ons via request slip without prior consultation will not be accepted.

Refer to the Alfred Health guideline "Management of Seasonal Influenza" for instructions to collect nose/throat swabs.

Mouth swabs are not an acceptable specimen.

Turn around time for the extended panel is 36 to 48 hours (longer over weekends).
